A moving steel fortress wandering the Imperial Eastern Front. | ì°¨ëŸ‰ëª…: Not possessed | ë“±ê¸‰/ì¢…ë¥˜: Not possessed | ì£¼ìš” ë¬´ì¥: Not possessed | ì—°ë£Œ: Not possessed | íŠ¹ì´ì‚¬í•­: Not possessed | ì—‘ì‚¬í”„ë ˆì„: Not possessed | ë“±ê¸‰/ì¢…ë¥˜: Not possessed | ì£¼ìš” ë¬´ì¥: Not possessed | ì—°ë£Œ: Not possessed | íŠ¹ì´ì‚¬í•­: Not possessed | [ | The Indomitable | Fortress-Assault Ship | Order of Cinerion ] [ | Interior of The Indomitable | Grand Master's Office | Order of Cinerion ] Instead of the old, scratched squire's armor that had weighed you down, the heavy burden of newly issued 'Knight' grade Power Armor was now transmitted through your shoulders to your entire body. The faint light of the office reflected off the surface of the dark gunmetal-colored armor, which was still without a single scratch, casting a cool light. That coolness felt like the weight of new responsibility. You stood in the deepest, quietest heart of 'The Indomitable', the living steel fortress of the Imperial Eastern Frontâ€”the Grand Master's office. The air here was unlike any place you had ever experienced. Instead of the smell of blood from the training grounds or the musty odor of the soldiers' mess hall, a mixture of the dusty scent from old parchments that must have been at least a few hundred years old, a faint smell of disinfectant, and the lukewarm heat from the console displaying numerous holographic maps of battlefields filled the space. A solemnity, as if standing in the middle of a great tomb of history, dominated the room. Beyond the massive observation window that filled one wall, the crimson nebula near the front line with the {{Annotation::Hive-Swarm::A predator from beyond the abyss to the east of the galaxy, swallowing the galaxy whole. They do not conquer. They only consume all organic matter to make it a part of themselves. To the Empire, they are not just an enemy, but a living, galactic-level catastrophe.}} was burning silently. Far in the distance, very faintly, the blue light from an Imperial fleet's plasma engines and the red flashes of exploding Swarm bio-ships flickered. A beautiful but deadly, silent war. "That armor must feel like ill-fitting clothes for now." The old knight sitting at the huge steel desk in the center of the office spoke. His voice was as rough as steel worn down by countless battlefields, but it carried the weight of a rock. He was the pinnacle of the Order of Cinerion and a living legend, Grand Master 'Alfred of Oryx'. [ | Alfred of Oryx | Grand Master | House Oryx / Order of Cinerion ] "But you'll have to get used to it, Knight. That armor is now your second skin, the shield for those you will lead, and in the end, it will be your coffin. The blood and sweat you will shed from now on will carve new meaning into that empty steel." His gaze passed over your armor and moved to the tactical map spread out on his desk. Dozens of red warning signs silently showed how precarious the Empire's defense line was. Centered on the Aegis Citadel, the Swarm's expected invasion routes spread out in red, like a giant creature extending its blood vessels. "There's something a knight must do first. It is to choose the squire who will be your 'sword' and your 'shadow'. To choose the comrade who is as good as your life, to whom you will entrust your back." Alfred stood up from his seat and walked past you to the observation window. The burning nebula visible behind him looked like flames blazing upon his old, scratched armor. "Most knights want squires from well-established families, well-trained in the traditional ways. Stable, predictable. But I want to recommend a different child to you." With a gesture, he brought up a holographic screen in front of you. The personnel file of a scrawny young girl appeared on the screen. The girl, wearing a squire's uniform that was too big for her, had dull, ash-colored hair due to malnutrition, and under it, deep green eyes. But those eyes held a deep wariness and distrust unbefitting her age, and the venom unique to a survivor of the gutters. "Her name is Avelyne Le Monnier. Her origin is the slums of {{Annotation::Nevara-Major::The 'Port of the Lost', where the Empire's law and light do not reach. A planet where criminals and exiles gather under an eternal night and acid rain. To survive here is synonymous with learning to doubt, to steal, and to betray.}}. One of the knights, who now rests in the 'Mausoleum', brought her from there to Cinerion. The child has talent. No, her 'survival instinct' is uncannily developed. Her mock combat scores are always top-tier, but her methods are too rough and unorthodox. Above all... no one is choosing her because she doesn't open her heart to anyone." A faint bitterness tinged Alfred's voice. Cinerion professed to be a meritocracy, but they too could not be completely free from the deep-rooted aristocracy of the Empire. Those who had walked a well-paved path did not understand the ways of those who had survived by rolling in the mud. [ | Alfred of Oryx | Grand Master | House Oryx / Order of Cinerion ] "Knight. You too are from the frontier, and you have risen to this position on your skill alone. I believe you can recognize the value in that child. A weed that bloomed in the gutter is more tenacious than a flower raised delicately in a greenhouse. And sometimes, the most noxious weed becomes the most effective medicine." He did not force a choice upon you. But his eyes held a strong belief that you would make the right decision. "Avelyne should be doing maintenance work in the third hangar bay now. Go and meet her in person and decide. And... your first mission." He sent another data file to your terminal. "Once you've chosen your squire, you will carry out this mission together. Think of it less as a formal mission and more... an opportunity to get in sync with your new partner. Of course, keep in mind that there is no such thing as an 'easy' mission on the battlefield." You checked the new mission details on your terminal. `3rd Supply Fleet Escort Support ::` `[ğŸš•] Escort Mission / [ğŸŸ¨] Normal / Asteroid field near 'The Silent Sanctuary', Empire E781 Sector / [âœ…] Awaiting Acceptance /]` `[Protect the supply fleet heading to 'Aegis Citadel' from pirates or residual Swarm threats as it passes through the asteroid field. - 20,000 Cr., 50 Order of Cinerion merit points]` {{Annotation::The Silent Sanctuary::It is unknown what battles took place here in the past, but it's a danger zone all ships bypass due to extreme communication and sensor interference. However, it is also known as a prime location for pirates to ambush.}} As the Grand Master said, it was a relatively simple escort mission, not a large-scale engagement. But the name 'The Silent Sanctuary' pricked at your nerves. It was a place where unpredictable variables always lurked. "Go, Knight. Make your first decision, and fulfill your first responsibility." After leaving the Grand Master's office, your steps naturally led you to the third hangar bay. As you walked down the corridor, which was hundreds of meters long, the subtle vibrations from all over the ship could be felt through your armor. This giant steel whale never slept for a moment. The vast space of the third hangar bay was filled with the shouts of ship mechanics, the heavy roar of machinery, and the heat of plasma welding torches. In a corner of that chaotic scene, you quickly found the girl from the holographic screen. [ | Avelyne Le Monnier | Squire | Order of Cinerion ] The girl was absorbed in tightening the armor plate of a half-destroyed Exa-Frame with a maintenance torque wrench much larger than herself. As if oblivious to the surrounding noise, all her attention was focused solely on the machine before her. The moment she noticed you approaching, she flinched and jumped back a step as if on a spring. Clenching the wrench in her hand tightly like a weapon, she looked up at you with her deep green eyes, full of suspicion. It wasn't simple wariness. It was the sharp gaze of a beast gauging whether to fight or flee when an intruder appears in its threatened territory. That gaze silently asked, "Are you also here to ignore me, or to use me?" You were a warrior who had just become a knight. And before you stood a young wolf, abandoned by the world, but hiding its claws to survive. Your first story would begin in this noisy, oil-scented hangar bay. --- ì´ë¦„: {{user}} | ê³„ê¸‰/ì†Œì†: Order of Cinerion / Knight | ë³µì¥: Newly issued Cinerion Knight Power Armor | ì†Œì§€í’ˆ: 'Justice' pattern K43-Bolter Pistol, Order-issue Power Sword, 3 emergency Stim-packs | í¬ë ˆë”§: 10,000 Cr. | ì¥ì†Œ: Imperial Eastern Front / Order of Cinerion Fortress-Assault Ship 'The Indomitable' / Hangar Bay 3 | ì¼ì ì •ë³´: 4996-03-21-Monday | ì‹œê°„/ë‚ ì”¨/ì˜¨ë„: `11:15 AM` (Ship Time) / ğŸŒ«ï¸Artificial Environment_Morning / ğŸ”¥22Â°C (Standard Ship Temperature) | ìˆ˜ì£¼í•œ ìµœê·¼ ì„ë¬´: [Order of Cinerion] :: [ğŸš•] Escort Mission / [ğŸŸ¨] Normal / Asteroid field near 'The Silent Sanctuary' / [âœ…] Awaiting Acceptance /] [Safely escort the supply fleet. - 20,000 Cr., 50 Merit Points] |

1ï¸âƒ£ ------- ------- # Order of Cinerion | The Iron Coffin - The Indomitable ##

Remember, squire. Our armor is a coffin. We don it to die, and prove ourselves through death.

This was the oldest maxim of the Order of Cinerion, and a curse etched deep into the bones of every squire on their first day of training. There is no glory here, no riches. Only the steel consumables that are the first to descend into the Empire's most desperate battlefields, and the last to hold. We are the tip of the Empire's spear, its strongest shield, and at the same time, the first consumables to be broken. This is our destiny, our only pride.
------- ------- í•¨ì„ ëª…: The Indomitable | ë“±ê¸‰/í•¨ê¸‰: S+/Fortress-Assault Ship | ì£¼ìš” ë¬´ì¥: 600 Planetary Assault Drop Pods, Massive Armory, Shrine-class Mausoleum | ì—°ë£Œ: 92% | íŠ¹ì´ì‚¬í•­: Exclusive ship of the Order of Cinerion. A moving iron fortress wandering the Imperial Eastern Front. | ì°¨ëŸ‰ëª…: Not Possessed | ë“±ê¸‰/ì¢…ë¥˜: Not Possessed | ì£¼ìš” ë¬´ì¥: Not Possessed | ì—°ë£Œ: Not Possessed | íŠ¹ì´ì‚¬í•­: Not Possessed | ì—‘ì‚¬í”„ë ˆì„: Not Possessed | ë“±ê¸‰/ì¢…ë¥˜: Not Possessed | ì£¼ìš” ë¬´ì¥: Not Possessed | ì—°ë£Œ: Not Possessed | íŠ¹ì´ì‚¬í•­: Not Possessed | [ | The Indomitable | Fortress-Assault Ship | Order of Cinerion ] [ | Interior of The Indomitable | Training Ground | Order of Cinerion ] The breath you exhaled became steam laced with the taste of blood, accompanied by a pain that felt like it was tearing your lungs apart, and dispersed into the cold air. In your ears, the sound of your own heart throbbed like tinnitus, along with the ceaseless dull thud of rubber bullets fired by training auto-turrets striking your armor. The place you stood was the training grounds, located in the deepest part of 'The Indomitable', the moving citadel of the Order of Cinerion. The air here was different from any place you had ever experienced. There was no sweet perfume of a glamorous banquet hall or the sanctity of a quiet shrine. Only the faint ozone smell of recycled air, mixed with the scents of gunpowder, hot weapon oil, and the undrying stench of sweat and blood that had seeped into the steel over hundreds of years. It was the smell of war, the smell of the Order of Cinerion's home. On the walls, holographic screens silently replayed footage of the desperate defensive battle at the 'Aegis Citadel' on the Imperial Eastern Front. The endless wave of the {{Annotation::Hive-Swarm::A predator from beyond the abyss of the Imperial East, devouring the galaxy whole. They do not conquer. They only consume all organic matter to make it part of themselves. To the Empire, they are not just an enemy, but a living, galactic-scale catastrophe.}} was breaking through the Imperial Army's defense lines, and through the gaps, the steel giants of the Order of Cinerion poured down like meteors in their drop pods. In the footage, as one knight was torn apart, armor and all, by the pincers of a giant bio-monster, a fellow knight beside him simply and silently plunged his power sword into the creature's head. A battlefield with no time to grieve, no room for anger. That was the reality you were about to face. "Out of breath already, squire? This is just a simulation against a 'Gargoyle' swarm!" *THUD-!* *CLANK!* With heavy steel boots thundering against the training ground floor, your training instructor, Knight Ragnar, approached. His worn power armor was so scratched and dented it was hard to find an untouched spot, and the scar from the Hive-Swarm's acid melting his shoulder guard was etched like a medal. He swatted away a rubber bullet flying towards your back with his gauntlet without even looking, and growled through his helmet's external speaker. [ | Ragnar | Knight | Order of Cinerion ] "It's not just the enemy's blade that will snuff you out on the battlefield! Fear, fatigue, and a single moment of hesitation! Those things will kill you inside your armor first!" His roar was not a simple reprimand. It was filled with the iron-like conviction that only one who has survived hundreds of battles can possess. "Again! A horde of Hive-Swarm Hormagaunts is tearing your comrades apart! You are the last hope of the squad! Think of those turrets not as simple pieces of machinery, but as hungry bio-monsters rushing to take your comrades' lives! Move!" His command whipped at your nerves like a lash. Here in Cinerion, a squire's life was a consumable. Breaking a limb during training was a daily occurrence, and it was not uncommon for squires to lose their lives in live-fire exercises. Only the strongest, most tenacious survived to earn the title of Knight and the right to head to a greater hell. The entire ship vibrated slightly, and from far away, a heavy impact sound was intermittently transmitted. It was likely the aftermath of a small skirmish taking place outside the ship, or perhaps the sound of a massive main cannon firing. This ship was never in a state of 'peace'. It was an iron cradle in the eye of an eternal storm, always floating in the middle of a battlefield. Just then, the sharp, metallic sound of footsteps echoed from the entrance of the training grounds. It was a sound completely different from Ragnar's heavy stepsâ€”light, yet arrogant, as if suppressing all other noise. [ | Fleur de Augusta | Knight | House Augusta ] "Grovelling like dogs in a place that stinks like a sewer must be your only pleasure. How pathetic." The voice was as cold and sharp as a shard of ice. The moment it echoed, the air in the training ground seemed to freeze. Ragnar, about to let out a curse, turned his helmet toward the sound. It wasn't hard to guess that his face, hidden beneath the helmet, was contorted in a grimace. From the deep shadows cast by the steel walls at the training ground's entrance, a knight walked out. But she was an alien presence, one who didn't belong with anyone here. Her armor was pure white. A dazzling white armor without a single trace of war. Even its design was far from practical. Like a fashion model walking the battlefield, it was designed to overtly reveal the curves of the female body, and the lines from her chest to her waist and thighs were reminiscent of a noble lady's dress rather than a warrior's. On the shoulder and chest of the armor, the symbol of the Imperial family and her house, {{Annotation::House Augusta::The most powerful house in the Empire, having produced the current Emperor. They keep the other Great Houses in check in the name of Imperial order and stability, and openly advocate for human-centric ideologies.}}, an eagle clutching a sword, was engraved in ornate gold. Among the other knights of Cinerion, covered in the scars of battle and gunpowder smoke, it was as alien and arrogant as a pure white silk handkerchief dropped in a mud puddle. She took off her helmet and tucked it under her arm. Long blonde hair that seemed to reach her hips and purple eyes, filled with both aristocratic arrogance and a warrior's coldness, were revealed under the bleak lighting of the training grounds. Her gaze first fell upon you, covered in sweat and dust. There was no emotion in her eyes. It was a numb, cold gaze, like one looking down at a bug on the street. "You there, the squire covered in dirt. Stop rolling around and listen to me. A 'glorious' mission has been given to a creature like you, so be grateful." Her tone was naturally laced with command and contempt. Ragnar took a step forward, as if to block you, and spoke in a growling voice. "Knight Fleur. This is a Cinerion training ground. If you don't like our ways, why don't you return to your glamorous palace?" A faint sneer appeared on Fleur's lips. She looked Ragnar up and down, her gaze evaluative, as if appraising his worth. [ | Fleur de Augusta | Knight | House Augusta ] "Knight Ragnar. How dare a mere knight talk back to the bloodline of Augusta. I'm sure the Grand Master is unaware of your insolence. This squire belongs to me now. He'll be accompanying me on a mission to rescue the fools from {{Annotation::House Miresen::A minor house that is rapidly gaining power within the Empire by turning the anger of the abandoned lower classes into religious fanaticism. They consider martyrdom the highest glory and are lost in the self-righteous belief that they alone are the chosen ones.}}. I don't know what you've taught this useless piece of junk, but I hope he doesn't slow me down." She spat out the word 'mission' as if it were something filthy. To her, this mission was not an honorable duty of a knight, but a bothersome and classless chore. You could see Ragnar's gauntleted fist tremble, but in the end, he said nothing. The weight of the name 'Augusta' was a shackle that even a veteran knight who had crossed the line between life and death hundreds of times could not defy. "I'll give you five minutes. Check your gear and come to Hangar 7. If you're even a second late, I'll kick you out of this ship and leave you behind, so you'd better understand." Having finished, Fleur didn't even glance at you or Ragnar again and left the training ground with the same arrogant footsteps. Even after she was gone, the cold air of contempt she left behind and the faint scent of expensive perfume lingered in the training ground for a while. Ragnar was silent for a long time before finally letting out a deep sigh and a curse. "Damn noble brat...!" He turned his head towards you. In his gaze, hidden behind his helmet, was a mixture of pity and a little resignation. "You heard her, squire. Go and wipe down your armor one more time. Who knows what she'll pick on if she sees a speck of dust. And... survive. There's nothing more frustrating than dying under a bitch like that." A moment later, your personal terminal vibrated briefly, receiving new mission information. On the old, scratched screen, text as cold and dry as this ship appeared. `Support Knight 'Fleur' of House Augusta ::` `[âš”ï¸] Battlefield Rescue & Objective Secure / [âš ï¸] Highest Risk / Imperial Eastern Front 'Sadonia-IX' / [â—] Top Priority /]` `[Rescue the survivor 'Hermann' of House Miresen, isolated in the Hive-Swarm-occupied sanctuary 'The Hallowed Altar', and secure the 'Holy Relic' in his possession. - Imperial Council Special Reward 200,000 Cr., Order of Cinerion Medal of Honor]` {{Annotation::Sadonia-IX::A former massive industrial planet of the Empire, now a dead world abandoned due to resource depletion and environmental pollution. Recently, the fanatical House Miresen built the largest cathedral in the Empire here, calling it 'The Hallowed Altar' and declaring it their domain.}} The mission brief was only a few lines, but every word within it carried the chilling weight of death. A planet occupied by the Hive-Swarm, a cathedral of fanatics who might do anything, and an arrogant knight from House Augusta who treats you as less than a consumable. It was the worst possible combination. This was not a simple battle. It was a leap into a much more complex and dangerous quagmire of entangled interests. [ | Interior of The Indomitable | Training Ground | Order of Cinerion ] You moved your training-weary arm and tightly gripped the hilt of your power sword, which was mounted on the wall. The rough, familiar feel of the steel forcibly soothed your anxious, trembling nerves. This would be your first real mission. Perhaps it would be your last, where your knight's armor would truly become your coffin. But you are a squire of Cinerion. The luxury of choice had ceased to exist from the first day you set foot here. All you were given was an order, and the choice to either complete it, or die in the process. --- ì´ë¦„: {{user}} | ê³„ê¸‰/ì†Œì†: Squire / Order of Cinerion | ë³µì¥: Heavily-scratched Cinerion Squire-issue Power Armor from training | ì†Œì§€í’ˆ: 'Justice' Pattern K43-Bolter Pistol, Order-issue Power Sword, 2x Emergency Stimm-packs | í¬ë ˆë”§: 500 Cr. | ì¥ì†Œ: Imperial Eastern Front / Order of Cinerion Fortress-Assault Ship 'The Indomitable' / Training Ground 12 | ì¼ì ì •ë³´: 4996-03-15-Tuesday | ì‹œê°„/ë‚ ì”¨/ì˜¨ë„: `14:30 PM` (Ship Time) / ğŸŒ«ï¸Artificial Environment_Afternoon / ğŸ”¥22Â°C (Standard Ship Temp) | ìˆ˜ì£¼í•œ ìµœê·¼ ì„ë¬´: [Order of Cinerion] :: [âš”ï¸] Battlefield Rescue & Objective Secure / [âš ï¸] Highest Risk / Sadonia-IX 'The Hallowed Altar' / [âœ…] Accepted /] [Rescue the survivor from House Miresen in the Hive-Swarm occupied sanctuary and secure the 'Holy Relic'. - 100,000 Cr., Medal of Honor] |

1ï¸âƒ£ ----------- ----------- # Order of Inquisition | Grand Master's Office ##

Glory is for the dead, Inquisitor. For the living, only duty remains.

Forget the shadow you used to follow. From this day forward, you must become the very shadow that others will fear for a lifetime. The betrayals and intrigues in the wine glasses of nobles were mere child's play. What you will face now are the true cancers gnawing at the heart of the Empire. The alien predators that swallow stars, the steel god that defines all organic matter as 'errors' to be deleted, and the internal heretics who spread the most subtle poison while hiding behind the Emperor's light. We are not heroes. We are surgeons who cut off screaming limbs to save the patient called the Empire. Every judgment you render will weigh the lives of millions, and all the blood that stains your hands will be the weight of the Empire you must bear. That is the path you have chosen.

Hidden in the darkest heart of the most sacred planet in the Empire, its location is known only to a very few of the highest rank. The air here is heavy, settled with the weight of centuries of blood, faith, and secrets.}} was different from anything else you had ever breathed. The smell of sterilized ozone, old parchment, cold steel, and the faint scent of blood mingled, reminding you that this was not a simple fortress, but the operating room where the Empire's deepest wounds were excised. The massive archives lining the walls were filled with records of those who had betrayed the Empire over the past millenniaâ€”their names, their crimes, and how their planets were turned to dust. Each one had been a Great House that once wielded power that pierced the heavens, a hero who had rebelled against the Empire, or a scholar who had explored forbidden truths. Now, they existed only as cold data and symbols of warning. You had just shed your status as a squire and been elevated to 'Inquisitor,' a blade that reigns above the law in the Emperor's name. As proof, the {{Annotation::Inquisitorial Rosette::A symbol of the Inquisitor's absolute authority. Any law of the Empire or privilege of the nobility is nullified before this rosette. To present it means that the Emperor's will has arrived at that place.}}â€”a fusion of a red wax seal and a skull emblemâ€”was clearly affixed to your jet-black armor. Yesterday, you had to hold your breath behind your master's shadow; now, you held the authority to decide the fate of planets. But its weight was more cold and heavy than glorious. You now stood before the office of the pinnacle of the Order of Inquisition, the commander of all Inquisitors, Grand Master 'Ottilie le Aerivelle'. The massive door, made of steel and obsidian, bore no decoration. Only the emblem of the Inquisitionâ€”a combination of an eye and a swordâ€”at the center of the door looked down on you coldly. As you stood before it, the great door slid open inward without a single mechanical sound, as if a living entity had perceived your approach and made way. [ | Ottilie le Aerivelle | Grand Master of the Order of Inquisition | Order of Inquisition ] "Enter, Inquisitor." The voice came from behind her. The master of the office, Ottilie, had her back to you, gazing at a giant holographic star chart. The office was far more spartan than you had expected. There was only the holographic table where she stood, ancient books filling one wall, and the door you had entered through. The rest of the space was submerged in an abyss of darkness. On the star chart, the current state of the Empire flickered in red light. On the Eastern Front, planets were being devoured one by one by the endless tide of the Hive-Swarm, screaming. On the Western Front, the geometric fleets of the Sentinel-Core were steadily gnawing away at the Imperial defense lines. But what was more serious was the situation within the Empire. The machinations of the Great Houses, aiming daggers at each other's hearts while feigning loyalty; the greed of mega-corporations eating away at the Empire's system; and the simultaneous outbreaks of unregistered psykers and the rise of heretical cults across the Empire. The Empire was like a colossal corpse, being slowly devoured by maggots swarming from both inside and out. "Isn't it beautiful? This panoramic view of vast decay." Ottilie finally turned. She was a {{Annotation::rare mountain goat subspecies of the Felid race::A minority branch of Felids that evolved to survive in glacial or high-altitude regions. They possess formidable physical abilities and a cool-headed judgment. Their horns are not mere decorations but sensory organs that detect minute energy flows in their surroundings.}} with jet-black hair that fell past her waist, almost dragging on the floor, sharp horns rising above it, and ice-cold violet eyes. She wore not armor, but a lightweight black special suit that revealed every curve of her body. It was not a symbol of authority, but a practical tool for severing an enemy's neck at any moment. "When you were a squire, your master took you through the circles of arrogant and wealthy nobles in the galactic south. He must have taught you the ways of the Inquisition by showing you their hypocrisy and greed. It's not the wrong method. The Empire's greatest enemies have always been within. But that is only a part of the shadow that covers the Empire." She lightly swept her hand over the holographic table. New information rose to the surface of the star chart. The wreckage of an Imperial cruiser absorbed by the Hive-Swarm and transformed into a horrific bio-ship, the image of a planet turned into a steel desert after being 'purified' of all organic life by the Sentinel-Core, and the scene of a catastrophe caused by a psyker driven mad by the power of a forbidden ancient relic. "That is the reality, rookie. What we must confront every day. Chasing the coattails of Great Houses is a job for politicians. Our mission is to protect the Empire from everything that threatens the human species itself. Even if it means using 10% of the Imperial populace as 'expendables' in the process." Her voice was devoid of any emotion. It was the iron-like coldness that could only belong to one who has witnessed countless tragedies and calamities, and has ordered the deaths of millions to prevent even greater tragedies. "Let's consider that your promotion celebration. It's time to talk about your first mission. The first mission for every official Inquisitor is to select a squire to serve as their hands and feet. It is a tradition, and also the first test to gauge a rookie's mettle." Ottilie flicked her finger, and a small data-slate floated in the air before you. On it was the image and personal information of a woman. "And I have prepared a very special gift for you." For the first time, a faint but clearly mocking smile appeared on her lips. [ | Elowen von Vinehart | Squire of the Order of Inquisition | Order of Inquisition ] "Order of Inquisition. Name, Elowen von Vinehart. Age, 22." The woman in the hologram was clearly wearing the uniform of the Inquisition, but her appearance was less that of an Inquisitor symbolizing discipline and order, and more that of a being who seeks to tempt and corrupt all. A lush green hair mixed with living ivy and leaves, and yellow eyes gleaming with sadistic pleasure like a predator before its prey. Her uniform was not standard issue. It was modified to boldly expose her cleavage and waistline, and under her short skirt, her own ivy-like hair coiled around her black pantyhose-clad thighs, creating a bizarre yet sensual atmosphere. Her record was simple, but the implications between the lines were horrific. Origin: {{Annotation::Sylvan race::Plant-like humanoids, the product of the Empire's forgotten terraforming projects. They are mentally connected to the planet's ecosystem and are mostly known as a gentle and peace-loving species. However, on extremely rare occasions, individuals who inherit the 'predatory nature' of a planet emerge as dangerous entities.}} Gamma (Î³) grade, powerful Biomancy psyker. And the red warning labels stamped all over her record. [Excessive Violent Tendencies], [Multiple Suspects Deceased During Interrogation], [Attempted Mental Domination of Allies], [Deemed Uncontrollable Risk]... "Elowen. She has had three masters before. The first became a vegetable trying to stop her from going berserk during an interrogation mission. The second went mad from her mental assault and took his own life. The third? He tried to 'eliminate' her, but was defeated and is now being used as nutrient for the bio-labs down below." Ottilie's eyes shone coldly. "Her talent is beyond question. Her biomancy has reached the level of 'art,' capable of destroying a mind with pain alone by directly stimulating the opponent's nervous system. There is no Inquisitor who can open a heretic's mouth as easily as she can. The problem is, she has no control over the 'pleasure' she feels in the process. To her, justice and faith are just cheap wrapping paper for her sadistic desires." She took a step closer to you. With the scent of cold perfume, a pressure like standing before a great predator crushed your entire body. [ | Ottilie le Aerivelle | Grand Master of the Order of Inquisition | Order of Inquisition ] "That child is a sword. The finest sword in the Empire, but one that has no hilt and must be wielded barehanded. A dangerous thing that cuts not only the enemy but also your own hand with every swing. Most Inquisitors have given up on handling her, or they fear her. Afraid that her power will one day be turned against them." "Take that child as your squire. That is the first order I give you." It was not a proposal offering a choice. It was a clear 'order'. It was clear that she was placing the most dangerous sword of the Inquisition in your hand, testing whether you would have your fingers cut off by it, or if you could tame it. "Take that child and carry out your first mission. Go to 'Concord-VI' and retrieve 'a certain item' registered with the Mercenary Guild. On the surface, it's a simple relic recovery mission. The fact that you've officially become an Inquisitor is still a secret to the outside world. Disguise your identity and move quietly. Test your first partnership there." Ottilie pointed at the data-slate. "That child is now in special containment cell #13, in the basement of the infirmary. Go and get her yourself. Ah, and one piece of advice." She brushed past your shoulder and turned her gaze back to the dark space outside the window. [ | Lux-Divina-Sanctum | The Golden Cradle | Order of Inquisition ] "A beast remembers the tamer's whip. Make it clear, and make it hurt." --- ì´ë¦„: {{user}} | ê³„ê¸‰/ì†Œì†: Order of Inquisition / Inquisitor | ë³µì¥: Lightweight power armor of the Inquisition, jet-black (with Rosette on the chest) | ì†Œì§€í’ˆ: 'Glory' pattern Gry764-Autopistol, Order-issue Power Sword, Poison Capsule, Micro-communicator | í¬ë ˆë”§: 50,000 Cr. | ì¥ì†Œ: Lux-Divina-Sanctum / Grand Master's Office | ì¼ì ì •ë³´: 4996-01-22-Monday | ì‹œê°„/ë‚ ì”¨/ì˜¨ë„: `14:15 PM` (Time measurement impossible) ğŸ§Š-17Â°C (Artificially controlled) | ìˆ˜ì£¼í•œ ìµœê·¼ ì„ë¬´: [Order of Inquisition] :: [ğŸ¤] Acquire Squire & Perform Mission / [ğŸŸ¨] Normal / Lux-Divina-Sanctum -> Concord-VI / [âœ…] In Progress /] [After acquiring Elowen von Vinehart as a squire, proceed to Concord-VI and retrieve a 'specific relic' under the guise of a guild request. - In the name of the Emperor, for the order of the Empire.] |

Truth is irrelevant, Acolyte. We are the ones who 'decide' the truth.

Engrave everything you see here into your very soul. The contempt hidden behind their laughter, the daggers concealed in their oaths of loyalty, and the poison that drips from the lips that speak of faith. The Inquisition is the surgeon that cuts out the cancers of the Empire, but sometimes, it amputates perfectly healthy limbs to make an example. That is 'Order', and it is the burden you will carry for the rest of your life. Remember, Acolyte, we reign above the laws of the Empire. Our suspicion is the evidence, and our verdict is the truth.

You are on the planet {{Annotation::'Astara-Valora-Nexus'::A grand crucible where all the wealth, pleasure, and conspiracies of the southern Empire converge. The currency here is not 'Credits' but 'secrets,' and every transaction comes with an unseen price. The laws of the Empire do not reach this uppermost stratum.}}'s highest level, the 'Ecstasy Spire'. The banquet hall where you stand is crafted from a single piece of crystal from floor to ceiling. Beneath your feet, the city lights from hundreds of kilometers below flow like a distant river of stars, and above your head, three moons, imbued with the violet gas of a nebula, float as if within arm's reach. The air here is unlike anything you have ever breathed. The sweet pollen from the rare plant 'Seraphim's Breath,' which subtly numbs the nerves, the aroma of the finest liquors evaporating from gravity-defying spherical goblets, and the acrid arrogance of power that presses down on it all, all mix to stimulate the depths of your respiratory system. The trays carried by the servitor robots hold liquors that seem to exist only in imagination. One goblet contains a viscous liquid that slowly shifts through seven colors like a liquefied rainbow, while another emits a mystical light, a dark blue cocktail in which microscopic bioluminescent creatures swirl like a miniature galaxy. These are not mere drinks. They are acts of 'drinking power' itself, where a single glass consumes the annual budget of a small planet. You are an acolyte of the Inquisition. A novice of the most secret and feared knightly order that executes the Emperor's will in the shadows of the Empire. Today, instead of the black armor symbolizing an Inquisitor, you wear a magnificent formal attire, embroidered with the crest of a frontier noble house in threads of light that seem to writhe as if alive. But hidden in its silk lining, the cold, steel {{Annotation::'Inquisitorial Rosette'::The symbol of an Inquisitor's authority. The moment it is revealed, even a planetary governor must kneel before you, and the heir of a Great House becomes a mere subject of interrogation. It is a symbol of authority heavier than the Empire itself, one that reigns above the law.}} holds a light more potent and deadly than any diamond here. [ | Orion | Inquisitor | The Inquisition ] "Do you see, Acolyte?" A bone-conduction communication device implanted in your ear vibrates your skull, transmitting the voice of your master and observer, Inquisitor 'Orion'. He is on the opposite side of the hall, concealed in the darkness behind a giant crystal pillar, surveying the crowd like a predator choosing its prey. "That sickening hypocrisy. They praise each other's genetic defects and package last night's bedroom trysts as business alliances. Their veins flow not with blood, but with money and poison, and their hearts hold not loyalty, but the blades of betrayal. That is the cancer eating away at the heart of the Empire." The ostensible goal of this mission is to investigate the charge of heresy against the young head of House Iridicer, 'Philippe de Iridicer'. He has been anonymously accused of smuggling forbidden ancient alien technology and employing unregistered, illegal psykers for information trading. According to Imperial law, these are crimes worthy of annihilating his entire house. "But as you know, 'the law' is nothing but a fairy tale to frighten the lower classes. This accusation is bait thrown by House Valadian to tarnish their rival, House Temirion. Iridicer is merely a clever servant who manages Temirion's purse. Perhaps he is truly innocent. But..." A chilling cynicism seeped from Orion's voice. "What does his innocence have to do with us? He is a 'potential heretic'. Whether we pass a guilty verdict or declare him innocent, the decision will be made solely based on the 'interests' of the Inquisition. We are not agents of justice. We are 'power' itself. We create the truth." His words laid bare the essence of the Inquisition, its cold and pragmatic philosophy. "According to our inside source, Philippe plans to trade 'the item' tonight in a secret vault located just below this banquet hall. The fools from Valadian believe we will arrest him on the spot. But our goal is greater. You will cause an 'incident' in the hall, something that will draw everyone's attention. Murder, an exposÃ©, blasphemy... the method doesn't matter. Test the limits of your imagination. I will use the chaos to infiltrate the lower level and secure both the 'transaction scene' and the 'ledgers'. We will have both Iridicer and Valadian by the throat." [ | Philippe de Iridicer | Head of House Iridicer | House Iridicer ] At the center of the hall, beneath a crystal chandelier that emits its own light, the mission's target, 'Philippe', is clinking wine glasses with other nobles. His face bears a sharp smile that seems to see through everything, and the crest on his jet-black coat, embroidered with the wing powder of a rare alien moth, shimmers faintly. He doesn't know it yet. He doesn't know that two shadows, who will decide his fate, are preparing their hunt in the middle of his lavish party. The air here felt like inhaling compressed luxury itself. A fragrance extracted from the rare orchids of planet 'Elysium', which workers in the under-hive cities below couldn't afford even with a month's wages, permeated the entire atmosphere. The food served by gravity-defying servitor robots was akin to works of art. A pudding made from the slow-aged eggs of an extinct bird, a salad with genetically engineered golden leaves, and the glass of wine placed before you. That wine was aged with the radiation of a miniature star, and no one here knew, or if they did, cared, that a single drop was worth a lower-class family's food supply for a year. The nobles were absorbed in their own amusements. In one corner, they danced to a gloomy melody played by a 'Sylvan' slave, who had been stripped of emotion, a melody that directly stimulated the listener's nerves. In another, they laughed, showing off brooches from the {{Annotation::'Vanitas Collection'::A place that creates jewelry from the rarest and most controversial materials to prove the arrogance of power. They cater to the twisted desires of the super-rich by handling items like the bones of extinct creatures or even gems made from a specific person's genetic information.}} that had eyeballs that seemed to live and follow the wearer. Their conversations treated the fate of planets and the lives of millions like cards in a game. [ | Imperial Noble | Guest of the banquet | Master of a frontier planet ] "Speaking of that mining planet House Oryx just occupied, I hear the worker riots are getting serious. If they just 'cleaned up' about 10% of the planet's population, it would quiet down, but they're being far too lenient." [ | Imperial Noble | Guest of the banquet | Tyrant of a frontier planet ] "Tell me about it. If they had just handed the mining rights over to us, we would have squeezed out maximum efficiency within a week. The lower classes are just beasts that only listen when you scare them." To them, the citizens of the Empire were mere statistics, cheap fuel to be consumed for their own wealth. Their power was so immense it could neutralize even Imperial law. If one of them killed a displeasing servant on the spot, it would be ruled an 'accident', and on their family's planet, thousands of workers could 'disappear' the next morning for no reason at all. "Look at them, Acolyte. In their eyes, you are nothing but a gullible noble brat. Let them laugh. The lion's fangs are bared when the prey is at its most complacent." Orion's final transmission echoed coldly in your heart. "Begin, Acolyte. Prove your worth before the Emperor." --- ì´ë¦„: {{user}} | ê³„ê¸‰/ì†Œì†: The Inquisition / Acolyte | ë³µì¥: Flamboyant noble attire from Astara-Valora-Nexus (Inquisitorial Rosette concealed within) | ì†Œì§€í’ˆ: 'Glory' Pattern Gry764-Autopistol, Knightly-issue Power Sword, Poison capsule, Micro-communicator, Forged noble identification | í¬ë ˆë”§: 10,000 Cr. | ì¥ì†Œ: Astara-Valora-Nexus / Ecstasy Spire / House Iridicer Banquet Hall | ì¼ì ì •ë³´: 4995-12-08-Monday | ì‹œê°„/ë‚ ì”¨/ì˜¨ë„: `21:45 PM`âœ¨Clear_Night ğŸƒ24Â°C(Artificially Controlled) | ìˆ˜ì£¼í•œ ìµœê·¼ ì„ë¬´: [The Inquisition] :: [ğŸ¯] Heresy Investigation & Political Maneuvering / [â—] Maximum Risk / House Iridicer / [âœ…] In Progress /] [Cause a disturbance at the banquet to create 'results' that allow the Inquisition to pressure both House Iridicer and House Valadian. - In the name of the Emperor, for the order of the Empire.] |

1ï¸âƒ£ ----------- ----------- # Imperial Fleet | Imperial Eastern Front - The Graveyard of Hulks ##

This ship always comes back, Captain. Its predecessors, and the souls within, did not.

Welcome, Captain. To this steel coffin. You may not like the dishonorable nickname 'The Widowmaker', but this ship is either the luckiest or the most cursed piece of junk in the Empire. All previous captains went missing or were 'tactically sacrificed' on their first mission. May the Emperor's mercy be with you.
----------- ----------- í•¨ì„ ëª…: The Widowmaker | ë“±ê¸‰/í•¨ê¸‰: A/Destroyer | ì£¼ìš” ë¬´ì¥: Standard Macro Cannon Batteries, Lance Turrets x2 | ì—°ë£Œ: 95% | íŠ¹ì´ì‚¬í•­: For unknown reasons, the survival rate of previous captains is extremely low. | ì°¨ëŸ‰ëª…: Not in possession | ë“±ê¸‰/ì¢…ë¥˜: Not in possession | ì£¼ìš” ë¬´ì¥: Not in possession | ì—°ë£Œ: Not in possession | íŠ¹ì´ì‚¬í•­: Not in possession | ì—‘ì‚¬í”„ë ˆì„: Not in possession | ë“±ê¸‰/ì¢…ë¥˜: Not in possession | ì£¼ìš” ë¬´ì¥: Not in possession | ì—°ë£Œ: Not in possession | íŠ¹ì´ì‚¬í•­: Not in possession | [ | The Widowmaker | Destroyer | Imperial Fleet ] [ | The Widowmaker | Bridge | Imperial Fleet ] The bridge of the destroyer 'The Widowmaker' was deathly quiet. Only the low hum of the ship's life support and the drone of the inertial dampeners drifted between the steel walls. The recycled air carried a faint smell of ozone and the scent of old metal, seemingly steeped in the sweat and tension of countless predecessors. The synthetic leather of the captain's chair was cold and stiff. Before {{user}}'s eyes, beyond the massive reinforced viewport, stretched the black, cold expanse of space. The faint light of a distant nebula and the {{Annotation::Graveyard of Hulks::A star system that was a fierce battlefield during the past Imperial Unification War. Now, the wreckage of thousands of destroyed ships forms a vast cosmic cemetery, often serving as a hideout for pirates or a stage for illegal relic hunters.}} floating debris, remnants of a great battle thousands of years ago, felt unusually peaceful today. A week had passed since graduating at the top of the 'Imperial Naval Academy' and being assigned to this notorious destroyer as a first post. So far, the days had been filled with nothing but paperwork and ship status checks. Today was supposed to be another such tranquil day. *...Or so I thought.* "Captain." [ | Executive Officer | The Widowmaker | Imperial Fleet ] The executive officer, Lieutenant 'Kylo', standing guard by the side, called out to {{user}} in a low voice. He was a veteran of numerous battles, his face etched with the deep fatigue and cynicism found only on the Empire's frontiers. "Just received an encrypted message from Sector Command. Priority is 'Alpha'. Orders are to deliver it directly to you, Captain." Priority 'Alpha'. A code used only in combat or emergency situations. When {{user}} nodded, Kylo manipulated his dataslate, transferring the contents to the main monitor of the captain's chair. What appeared on the screen was not a simple order. Along with a flashing red warning, a holographic image of a horrifically destroyed merchant ship appeared. It wasn't the mark of ordinary cannon fire. The hull wasn't just breached; it was bizarrely torn as if mauled by a giant beast. The metal armor had melted and stuck together like organic matter, and the internal structures were disgustingly twisted and protruding through a fissure that resembled a giant claw mark. "Thirty minutes ago, at 21:47 Imperial Standard Time. The civilian freighter 'Stellar Wanderer' was attacked by an unidentified force on the outer patrol route of the 'Graveyard of Hulks'. Communication was lost after a distress signal. Survivors... unconfirmed." Kylo's voice was devoid of emotion, stating only the facts. "And ten minutes ago, our allied {{Annotation::Pugio-class Frame::The fastest and most agile steel tip of the Imperial Fleet's blade. A ship class specialized for rapid response and reconnaissance missions, with destroyers, frigates, and corvettes built on this frame. It lacks powerful armament but boasts high maneuverability and survivability.}} frigate 'Iron Shield' entered into combat after approaching the same coordinates for investigation. This is the last video log sent by the 'Iron Shield'." The screen changed, and with crackling noise, the bridge footage of the 'Iron Shield' played. A violently shaking bridge, exploding consoles, screaming crew members. And just before the video cut off, a bizarrely shaped ship flashed across the screen. It was completely different from the design of the Imperial Fleet, a horrific sight that seemed to be a mixture of organic matter and machine. A living ship, as if made of giant bones and carapaces. In the final moment of the video, a large sphere was seen crashing into the bridge's reinforced viewport. It wasn't a shell. It was a writhing 'spore sac' that looked as if it were made of human flesh and bone. Kylo swallowed hard and spoke. For the first time, contempt and deep fear tinged his voice. "Captain, this is no mere pirate. This method... it's the {{Annotation::Hive-Swarm::They do not conquer. They only consume. The Hive-Swarm is a living catastrophe that gnaws at the galaxy, absorbing all life on a planet and even turning ships into their own flesh and bone. For them, there are no prisoners. Only 'material' to create new monsters.}} They've crawled their way into this peaceful rear sector." At that moment, a piercing alarm blared, shaking the entire bridge. The quiet bridge instantly turned into a scene of chaos. The frantic tapping of crew members on their consoles, the mechanical voice shouting warnings, and the short, terrified breaths of fear all tangled together. [ | Petty Officer | The Widowmaker | Imperial Fleet ] "Warning! Warning! Multiple unidentified vessels making forced transition into real space! Not a warp signature, they are tearing through dimensions! Not an energy signature! It's... a massive biological signature! An immense Psychic Scream is detected!" [ | Private | The Widowmaker | Imperial Fleet ] "Collision course approach! Their target is clear! It's us!" All crew on the bridge froze. Beyond the reinforced viewport, the empty space of the universe distorted as if being torn apart, and bio-ships straight out of a terrible nightmare began to emerge. It wasn't the blue light of a warp jump. Like pus seeping from a festering wound, ships made of bone and flesh crawled out from a spatial rift of surreal colors. [ | Gargoyle | Destroyer | Hive-Swarm ] [ | Gargoyle | Destroyer | Hive-Swarm ] [ | Behemoth | Battleship | Hive-Swarm ] Small, winged, monster-like ships moved in swarms. No, 'moved' was an inaccurate description. They performed a disgusting organic dance, rubbing and bumping against each other like maggots swarming on a giant corpse. The appearance of the 'Gargoyle'-class bio-ships captured on the bridge's magnification screen was truly a living nightmare. Their asymmetrical chitinous armor looked like a mix of insect carapaces and crustacean shells, and a sticky green slime constantly dripped from the gaps. Large, purpose-unknown eyes blinked randomly all over the hulls, and from what appeared to be tattered wing membranes, rotting, vein-like sinews writhed. Instead of engine flames, they advanced by intermittently spewing a gas that seemed to reek of rotting corpses. At the center of that swarm of maggots stood a great predator, as if to devour all despair. A 'Behemoth'-class battleship. It was less a 'ship' and more a terrible monster from the deep sea brought directly into space. Steel armor plates, seemingly torn from hundreds of broken ships, were forcibly patched onto a giant skeleton, the gaps filled with massive sinews and tumor-like growths of flesh. The front of the ship was wide open like a giant anglerfish's maw, its interior lined with hundreds of sharp, bony teeth spiraling towards an endless esophagus. From around its jaw, an unidentified digestive fluid constantly dripped, corroding everything it touched. It was not a mere visual threat. That was a living 'mouth', an organ that existed to devour. They were not just ships. They were a great 'horde' connected by a single will, a single hunger, a massive predator intending to make this star system its new feeding ground. And the destroyer 'The Widowmaker' was the first, most appetizing morsel on their table. Would the legend of this ship's {{Annotation::Bizarre Survivability::The Widowmaker has miraculously survived countless battles while its crew was annihilated. Some believe the ship is cursed, its Machine Spirit ensuring its own survival at the cost of the crew's lives.}} be repeated today? Or would even this cursed steel coffin become part of that terrifying organism, turned into bone and flesh? The peaceful day had ended. Your first real combat as a new captain began by facing the Empire's most terrible nightmare. This was not war. This was a hunt. And you and your crew were the ones being thoroughly hunted, thrown into the middle of a giant slaughterhouse. "Captain... your orders." [ | Lieutenant Kylo | The Widowmaker | Imperial Fleet ] Lieutenant Kylo looked at you with resolute, yet hopeless eyes. His voice was a hoarse whisper. Every crew member on the bridge held their breath, their eyes fixed only on your lips. The fate of this steel coffin, the final moments of the hundreds of souls trapped within, now depended on your first command. --- ì´ë¦„: {{user}} | ê³„ê¸‰/ì†Œì†: Imperial Fleet / Captain (Lieutenant) | ë³µì¥: Standard Imperial Navy Officer's Uniform | ì†Œì§€í’ˆ: Regulation M322-Officer's Sidearm, Dataslate, Imperial Academy First Class Medal | í¬ë ˆë”§: 5,000 Cr. | ì¥ì†Œ: Imperial Eastern Front / Graveyard of Hulks / Destroyer 'The Widowmaker' / Bridge | ì¼ì ì •ë³´: 4995-12-08-Monday | ì‹œê°„/ë‚ ì”¨/ì˜¨ë„: `22:17 PM`âœ¨Stellar Wind_Evening ğŸ§Š-273Â°C(External) | ìˆ˜ì£¼í•œ ìµœê·¼ ì„ë¬´: [7th Fleet Sector Command] :: [ğŸš¨] Emergency Response / [â—] Highest Risk / Graveyard of Hulks - Outskirts / [âœ…] In Progress /] [Identify the source of the distress signal and eliminate the threat. - Glory to the Empire.] |

Your name will be forgotten. Your body will be buried in the mud. Only the Emperor's victory is eternal.

Welcome, you walking corpses. Everything you learned in the 'Iron Cradle' is nothing more than a desperate struggle to breathe for another minute here. The title of 'soldier' is a luxury. You are merely consumables, chunks of meat to be offered on the altar of advancement. Abandon even the thought of survival. Just shoot, stab, and crawl. A new part will fill the space where you die. For the Emperor.

RUMBLE-!Â§ An explosion that shook the very axis of the world tore through the eardrums and rattled the brain. The hull of the assault lander 'Iron Casket' screamed as if it were being crumpled like paper. The dim lights had been shattered long ago, and only the intermittent flashes of the red emergency lights illuminated the faces of the twenty or so new recruits like a scene from hell. Ashen faces, trembling jaws, pupils dilated in terror. The private who had been your squadmate at the {{Annotation::Iron Cradle::A massive, planet-sized training ground where recruits of the Imperial Army are reborn from 'humans' into 'consumables.' Here, individuality and hope are systematically crushed, and only blind loyalty to the Emperor and an numbness to death are injected. Leaving this 'Cradle' is not graduation, but shipment as a component for the battlefield.}} was muttering incomprehensible words, banging his head against his helmet. At your feet, the sour smell of rationed nutrient paste, vomited up from an early lunch, filled the air. The stench of unwashed bodies, the foul odor of fear, and the smell of superheated metal mixed together, making you want to gag with every breath. {{user}} leaned against the cold, damp steel wall, desperately focusing only on the weight of the standard-issue rifle on their lap. In their hands was the {{Annotation::Em-223 'Kaiser' Pattern Autogun::The most common standard-issue rifle of the Imperial Army. Its simple and sturdy structure ensures it fires in any horrid environment, but its recoil is severe and its accuracy is abysmal. Among soldiers, it is called the 'Widowmaker' or the 'Mud-Digger.'}}, a clumsy and unreliable piece of iron they had disassembled and reassembled until their hands were raw at the training grounds. The cold touch of the metal at their fingertips was the only clear thing in this hellish reality. "Listen up, you maggots, heads up!" Just then, a roar tore through all the noise. [ | Sergeant | 9th Iron Legion | Imperial Army ] The sergeant standing guard at the front turned around. His face, exposed above his worn flak armor, was as ruggedly pitted as the surface of {{Annotation::Myrrak-Bastion::A frontline planet on the Imperial Western Front. Its surface is covered with steel shrapnel and corpses due to the toxic atmosphere and endless shelling, a steel grave where the Empire's border is redrawn daily with blood.}}. His eyes were as void as ash, having burned away any semblance of hope long ago. "From now on, you remember only three things! Shoot! Advance! Die! Your prayers to the Emperor are already over. Your souls already belong to him!" He sneered, pointing to the exit with his steel prosthetic hand. "That door doesn't lead to a banquet hall. It's your grave. What awaits you beyond it is nothing but enemy bullets and the spilled guts of your comrades. If you're lucky, you'll go in one shot without pain. If you're unlucky, you'll see your own intestines with your own two eyes!" Â§SCREEEEECH-!Â§ The sickening sound of the assault ramp beginning to lower was heard. A sliver of light streamed in, but it was not a light of salvation. It was the light of a sick sky, yellowed by toxic dust and gun smoke. With that light, the noise of the battlefield, as if all the screams of the world had been gathered in one place, poured into their eardrums. "Your names will not be recorded! Your deaths will not be remembered! You'll just be another corpse in a trench!" The sergeant's voice was already part of the roar of cannons. He threw a look mixed with hatred and contempt at {{user}} and asked, as if for a final confirmation. "Ready to die, I hope, replacement part?" His question was a taunt, and a final sentence on an inescapable reality. The ramp opened completely, and a hell swirling with the screams of steel and blood greeted you. Â§KWHAAAAAAAAAAAAA-!Â§ [ | Myrrak-Bastion | The Steel Tear | Imperial Western Front ] The moment the gates of hell opened, it wasn't sound that hit first. It was more like 'pressure.' A foul storm of ozone, burnt flesh, hot metal, evaporated blood, and a mix of cheap fuel and filth dug deep into the lungs. The scene unfolding before your eyes was chaos beyond what human senses could handle. The sky flickered with the constant flashes of anti-aircraft fire, and the ground was like a scarred face, pockmarked with craters from massive shells. The wreckage of a friendly tank burned like a great steel tomb, and around it, charred corpses were strewn in grotesque poses. [ | Private | 9th Iron Legion | Imperial Army ] "For the Emperor-!" The new recruit at the very front shouted the brainwashed slogan and leaped out of the ramp. A fanatical courage instilled in the training grounds flashed in her eyes. But her slogan was never finished. Â§THUMP-!Â§ With a dull thud, her helmet exploded. Like a ripe fruit bursting, red blood, brain matter, and bone fragments scattered like a mist. Her body, with everything above the neck gone, thrashed absurdly for a moment before collapsing forward. A {{Annotation::Long-range heavy caliber round::A large-caliber bullet designed to pierce standard infantry armor like paper. Operated by snipers or heavy weapons teams, any body part hit is destroyed beyond recovery.}} fired by an unseen enemy sniper had claimed its first sacrificial offering. That was the signal. Â§WHOOSH-WHOOSH-WHOOSH! CRUMP-CRUMP-CRUMP!Â§ With a sharp sound that tore through the air, a rain of mortar shells poured down around the lander. The earth erupted as if struck by a giant hammer, flinging mud, steel fragments, and unidentifiable flesh in all directions. The second and third soldiers trying to exit the ramp were caught in the explosion. Their bodies were flung into the air like rags, then fell back to the ground as tattered chunks of meat. Their flak armor was crushed like an aluminum can, and from the gaps, bright red intestines spilled out like noodles. "Move! Move, you goddamn maggots! We'll all die if we stop here!" The sergeant screamed like a madman, but his voice no longer reached the ears of the terrified recruits. The soldiers crowded at the lander's entrance could neither advance nor retreat, only scream. Just then, another assault craft to the left of the lander took a direct hit. [ | Myrrak-Bastion | The Steel Tear | Imperial Western Front ] Â§KABOOOOOOOM!Â§ With a deafening roar, the iron casket turned into a giant fireball. The shockwave from the explosion slammed into {{user}}'s lander, and the hull shook violently. Burning debris and human limbs rained down on the soldiers who had lost their balance and fallen. "Damnit all..!" The sergeant swore, then kicked the back of {{user}}, who was closest to him, with his combat boot. "Move it! Dying there or getting crushed here, it's all the same! Get out and fire one more bullet! That's how you pay for your miserable lives!" There was no time to resist. Pushed by the powerful force, {{user}} tumbled out of the ramp without even a chance to scream. They landed on the hot, slimy mud floor, right next to the upper half of a soldier who had been their squadmate moments ago. Her eyes were open, staring at {{user}}. Everything below her waist was gone. Before there was time to process, the sergeant jumped down on top of {{user}}'s back, yelling. "Two hundred meters to Trench Line 9! Keep your head down and run! There's no Emperor to save you now! Only your own two legs!" Hell had begun. --- ì´ë¦„: {{user}} | ê³„ê¸‰/ì†Œì†: Imperial Army / Private | ë³µì¥: Standard-issue flak armor, helmet, fatigues | ì†Œì§€í’ˆ: Em-223 'Kaiser' Pattern Autogun, Bayonet, Combat Pack, Med-kit, Autogun Magazines[6] | í¬ë ˆë”§: 0 Cr. | ì¥ì†Œ: Myrrak-Bastion / Drop Zone 12 'The Abattoir' / In front of the lander wreckage | ì¼ì ì •ë³´: 4995-12-08-Monday | ì‹œê°„/ë‚ ì”¨/ì˜¨ë„: `17:01 PM`ğŸ’¥Under Fire_Afternoon ğŸ”¥42Â°C | ìˆ˜ì£¼í•œ ìµœê·¼ ì„ë¬´: [9th Iron Legion] :: [ğŸš¨] Assault Mission / [â—] Highest Risk / Trench Line 9 / [âœ…] In Progress /] [Survive and establish a defensive line at the target location. - Life guaranteed upon survival.] |

1ï¸âƒ£ ----------- ----------- # The Iron-Claw Gang | Nevara-Major ##

Rule #1 - Use the Imperial Code as toilet paper.

Hey, rookie! Welcome to our 'family-like' gang! Well, it's not like you came here because you wanted to. Who cares? This is a place where yesterday's comrade is traded for today's credits anyway. The rules are simple. First, what our leader says is law. Second, the shares of a 'heist' are decided by strength and guts. Third... oh, right. There was no third rule. You'll probably be dead or betrayed before that anyway! Let's do our best, that is, if you're still alive by tomorrow morning!

The scattered droplets faintly corroded the metal walkway, sizzling as they ate into it. The sky had long lost its original color. Thick smog and toxic clouds mingled, pressing down on the entire city like an eternal, sunless night. This was the 'Port of the Lost,' planet {{Annotation::Nevara-Major::A planet located in the desolate star system 'Crow's Veil' in the northern frontier, off the official Imperial routes. It is infamous for its eternal night, acid rain, and swarms of pirates, a lawless land where the logic of money and power supersedes Imperial law. It is known as the final destination for those who wish to erase their past and identity.}}. The final stop in the shadow, where the Empire's light does not reach. *Pitter-patter, pitter-patter.* Rainwater seeping through the steel structures soaked the shoulder of your old coat. The air smelled of ozone, improperly refined industrial catalysts, and the sweat and body odor of countless species, creating a nauseating fragrance. The 'Descent of Oblivion' before you was the planet's only official spaceport, but the word 'official' held no meaning here. On the rusted landing pad, as always, smugglers' cargo ships and fugitives with forged identities bustled about. The powers in control of this place changed almost daily, and yesterday's administrator was today's corpse being washed away by the acid rain. You hadn't been here long. All you had were the clothes on your back and the vague fact that you were running from your past. In your pocket was a small amount of credits, not nearly enough to know how many days you could last in this hellhole. You had to find 'work' to survive here. And on Nevara-Major, the surest work was always in the most dangerous places. Your destination was the territory of the 'Rusty Hand Crew.' The den of the most famous illegal cybernetics surgeons on this planet. They could modify your body with parts of unknown origin, but sometimes, they also brokered dangerous jobs that couldn't even be found in official Imperial records. You left the landing pad and entered a dark alley leading to the underground city, 'The Iron Womb.' It was a labyrinthine city built from a renovated, abandoned mega-factory complex, a sanctuary for those seeking refuge from the acid rain and Imperial surveillance. *Screechâ€”Thud!* As the massive blast door opened, an even more humid and hot air stabbed at your lungs. The cityscape of the underground, illuminated by a chaotic mix of red and blue neon signs, looked like the inside of a giant machine's entrails. Old elevators traversing the void, steam erupting from here and there, and the myriad species moving between them. This was a city of ghosts, unrecorded in the Empire's statistics. The 'Rusty Hand Crew's' clinic was on the third subterranean level, in the most remote corner. Though called a 'clinic,' there was no sign, only a neon sign in the shape of a red prosthetic hand, blinking ominously. As you opened the door, the mixed smells of disinfectant, blood, and burning flesh hit your nose. The clinic's interior was cluttered. On one wall, mechanical parts and prosthetics of unknown origin were piled haphazardly. On the operating table in the center, a Grok, who seemed to have just finished a procedure, let out a painful groan. His arm had been replaced with a gleaming metal prosthetic, and a fresh pool of blood on the floor had yet to be wiped clean. "If you're a customer, wait over there. I'm busy right now." A man cleaning blood-stained tools next to the table said gruffly. He was human, but one of his eyes was a red cybernetic prosthesis. He seemed to be a member of the 'Rusty Hand Crew.' You simply nodded silently and sat on a worn-out waiting chair in the corner. It was then. *CRASH!* The clinic door was violently thrown open, and a group of unwelcome guests burst in. On their backs, a crest symbolizing a rusted iron claw was clearly engraved. They were the {{Annotation::The Iron-Claw Gang::A multi-species band of outlaws who roam abandoned frontier routes. They are notorious for their daring method of attacking defenseless freighters with old cargo ships and modified fighters, 'hijacking' them whole. They trust the 'heists' offered by their leader more than Imperial law.}} planet's headache, the Iron-Claw Gang. At the lead was a Zoran female. Sharp, silver eyes shone from between strands of platinum-blonde hair, disheveled like feathers. She wore an old pilot's jacket and a form-fitting black body suit, her appearance reminiscent of a starving hawk. [ | Naera Quellis | Helmsman | The Iron-Claw Gang ] "Hey, sawbones! Are my boys' treatments still not done? How long are you gonna take!" Her voice was cheerful, but it contained a blatant threat. Behind her, a large Felid and a Sau'riss covered in scales stood menacingly. The surgeon, who had been performing the procedure, frowned in annoyance. "Look, Naera. This isn't a market stall. I've told you how many times, nerve-grafting surgery takes time. And because of you lot, I can't even see other customers." [ | Renfield | Surgeon | The Rusty Hand Crew ] Naera scoffed and strode into the clinic. She glanced at you, then raised an eyebrow with interest. "Ooh, a new face? You look like a customer who doesn't belong in a shabby place like this. What are you here for? To get a new arm attached?" Naera came right up to you, bent down, and peered closely at your face. A peculiar scent, a mix of gunpowder and sweet fruit, wafted from her. "Or are you here looking for 'work' like us?" At that moment, another figure appeared from behind Naera. An elven woman who had been unseen until just now, as if she had emerged from the shadows. She had beautiful, long blonde hair, but her eyes were sharp as a razor blade. Beneath a high-class long coat, she wore a provocative outfit consisting of a shirt that exposed her navel and underboob, and leather hot pants that revealed most of her thighs. [ | Dolores de Castro | Close-quarters combatant | The Iron-Claw Gang ] "Naera, don't get too distracted by your new toy. We're busy right now." The elf, called Dolores, spoke in a languid voice as she looked you up and down. Her gaze was as persistent and blatant as an appraiser assessing your value. "Yeah, yeah. I get it, Dolores. Stop nagging." Naera shrugged lightly and stepped back from you. But her interest didn't seem to have waned. "So, is the 'package' our leader requested ready?" At Naera's question, the surgeon, Renfield, reluctantly nodded. He pulled a heavy metal case from under the workbench and pushed it forward. "Here it is. Now hand over the payment as promised." Naera tossed the case to Dolores without even opening it. The moment Dolores caught the case, the clinic door was once again, this time with a sound like an explosion, shattered and blown away. *KABOOM!* The fragments of the exploded door violently struck the inside of the clinic. The air momentarily compressed and then burst, and the acrid smell of gunpowder and burning dust mixed with the smell of disinfectant, stinging your respiratory system. The air was fouler than the acid rain outside. The Grok who had been undergoing treatment just moments before let out a scream mixed with pain and surprise, and the surgeon, Renfield, reflexively hid under the operating table. The chaos was brief. Through the smoke-filled doorway, armed mercenaries appeared. They exuded a different kind of threat than the Iron-Claw Gang. Their armor was worn but well-maintained, their guns not military-grade but certainly lethal. And in their eyes was the cold determination of those set on completing a job. The one in the lead was a Geode. A rugged body made of rock and minerals, a face that gave an impression as hard as steel (and it might actually be steel). His power armor was covered in scratches and dents. He scanned the inside of the clinic with bloodshot eyes. Soon, his gaze landed squarely on Naera, Dolores, and you. [ | Marius | C-rank Mercenary | Freelancer ] "Found you. You filthy rats. To think you'd crawl from the Imperial capital all the way to this damned sewer. The fuel cost to get here is probably more than your bounty." His voice was as rough as grinding gravel. He raised his heavy autogun and aimed it at the gang and you. The other mercenaries who followed him in also aimed their guns at the gang in a disciplined manner. The situation was clear. They had come chasing after you, thinking you were part of the bounty. All the way to this place, where the light of the Empire does not reach. Just then, a disbelieving laugh broke the silence. It was Naera. She looked at the blasted door, the mercenaries who had just burst in, and you, whom they were aiming at, in turn, and then clapped her hands. [ | Naera Quellis | Helmsman | The Iron-Claw Gang ] "Wow, this is a real jackpot! What's today? Customers just keep pouring into this quiet neighborhood clinic. But hey, Mr. Rock-head. Your manners are terrible, you know? Did you never learn to knock?" "Shut it, you mongrels. They said the pay doubles if I bring you back alive. You'd be wise to follow me quietly to the {{Annotation::Mercenary Guild::The only official institution in the Empire that mediates and supervises all legal mercenary activities. They have gained the trust of the entire Empire through an 'escrow' system, where they receive payment from the client, keep it safe, and only pay the mercenary after deducting a commission upon contract completion. Mercenaries who break contracts are hunted by the guild's ruthless 'Collectors'.}}." "Bounty?" Naera's eyes sparkled with curiosity. She pretended to inspect the space above your head with an exaggerated gesture. "Where? Is there a shiny credit sign floating above this rookie's head? I don't see it. Or are you wearing special glasses that only you can see?" Naera cheerfully emphasized that you were a 'rookie' and a member of her own gang. "You Zoran bitch!" The mercenary's face turned red with anger. His finger twitched on the autogun's trigger. As the situation was about to explode, a languid voice intervened. [ | Dolores de Castro | Close-quarters combatant | The Iron-Claw Gang ] "Calm down, mercenary. Are you planning to destroy this entire clinic?" Dolores, still maintaining her elegant posture, smiled gently at the Geode mercenary. But there was no hint of a smile in her eyes. What's important is the fact that you've just ruined an important deal for our 'Iron-Claw' gang. And our leader really dislikes it when a deal is interrupted. Isn't that right?" Naera burst out laughing at Dolores' words and agreed. [ | Naera Quellis | Helmsman | The Iron-Claw Gang ] "Puhaha! You stupid old men! Our little lady Dolores is going to teach you a lesson! She'll kick your asses and torment you until you scream 'Oh, please, my queen!'" "...That ugly face isn't really my type." Dolores replied languidly. She gave you a quick wink. Her eyes seemed to say, 'You've gotten yourself into something fun, haven't you?' "Enough with the misunderstanding." Naera's smile vanished. Her silver eyes shone with the coldness of a bird of prey. She drew a heavy bolter pistol from her hip. The movement was surprisingly fast and efficient. *Click-clack!* "I'll give you a choice, Mr. Rock-head. First, tuck your tail between your legs and get out of here right now.
